title: James Warburton skips AFL coronation for mum’s birthday
text:
One notable absence from the AFL Commission’s dignitary-heavy grand final luncheon in the MCG’s Olympic Room on Saturday was Seven West Media’s new chief executive James Warburton.

His predecessor Tim Worner, a close friend of AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan, was always a fixture at the head table with Aussie rules’ other broadcasters, Patrick Delany of Foxtel and Andy Penn of Telstra. This year, AFL chairman Richard Goyder had to settle for proprietor Kerry Stokes and Seven Group CEO Ryan Stokes as representatives of the free-to-air network. As we forewarned, this gig is all chiefs and no Indians.

Seven West Media chief executive James Warburton: has his priorities. James Alcock

Mr Ambitious – as David Leckie labelled him in unhappier times – was in Melbourne attending the Brownlow Medal function on Monday, so at least made an early appearance at the Festival of the Boot. But by Saturday he’d escaped to Lord Howe Island for his mother’s 80th birthday. You only get one family – and six years ago, the media executive tragically lost his father Richard, who was fatally hit by a ute while walking to a pilates class. Mrs Warburton had encouraged her husband to get out more.

Here’s hoping the family knees-up wasn’t too disruptive to the local black rat population.

Also in the Olympic Room – although not on the top table – was Southern Cross Austereo CEO Grant Blackley, who Ten Network’s boss Leckie delighted in referring to in interviews as Gert Clackley, Greg Cackley or any other vague iteration of his actual name. The magic of television!

Rounding out the TV luminaries was another former Ten CEO in Hamish McLennan, now sitting pretty as chairman of REA Group and HT &E, and as deputy chairman of Hamish Douglass’ funds management giant Magellan.
description: His predecessor Tim Worner was always a fixture at the head table with Aussie rules’ other broadcasters,
